body:
I was interested by this suggestion,

> * [ ]  `**` for applying a transformer to `X` into a forecaster, via `ForecastingPipeline`

 though I was wondering if you could clarify what you were envisioning here as I wasn't sure exactly what you had in mind.  Was it something like this:

`new_pipe = trans**forecaster`

so that it is essentially as if we did this:

` new_pipe = ForecastingPipeline(steps=[trans, forecaster])`

or perhaps more something like this:

`new_pipe = trans**pipe`

where `pipe` would some pre-existing `ForecastingPipeline` (with n steps s.t. n >= 1) and we wished to prepend `trans` to its `steps` attribute?  (and which to me at least seems like it would be the easiest to implement)

Or perhaps something that supports both?  So one could do:

`new_pipe = trans_1**trans_2**trans_3**...**trans_n**forecaster`

In truth, I would be curious as to your thoughts on use cases as it seems like all the cases I listed could be achieved by creating a new `ForecastingPipeline` with the desired transformations/forecasters added as steps?  

Realize I might be off base entirely here, thanks for your patience if that is the case!

> Or perhaps something that supports both? So one could do:

Yes, exactly!

This behaviour is actually already implemented for single `*` and the `TransformedTargetForecaster`, if you look at the dunder methods both in that class and in `BaseForecaster`. There are multiple behaviours, depending whether you are dealing with pipelines or not. The aim is to keep the pipeline structure flat, not nested. In total, there are four cases, depending on whether `self` or `other` is already a pipeline, or not:

If `*` is put between a transformer `a` and a forecaster `b`, 
* if neither of which are a pipeline, then a `TransformedTargetForecaster` is created with `steps=[a, b]`.
* if `a` is not a pipeline but `b` is, then `a` is prepended to the steps of `b` in a copy
* if `a` is a pipeline and `b` is not, then the steps of `a` are taken out of the transformer pipeline, `b` is appended, and a `TransformedTargetForecaster` is created
* if both are pipelines, then the steps from `a` are prepended to the steps of `b` in a copy, and the modified `b` copy is returned.

> Realize I might be off base entirely here, thanks for your patience if that is the case!

Don't say sth like that. This was one of the most sensible comment on pipelines I've read on sktime.
Your ideas are precisely the right ones imo.

What I'm thinking about is the problem of having separate pipelines to apply transformers to `X` and to `y`, i.e., the `ForecastingPipeline` and the `TransformedTargetForecaster`.

Construction, and handling the symbolic parsing via dunders seems to be more streamlind if there were a single pipeline object that handles both steps applied to `X` and to `y` - and, to me, it also seems like the only way to avoid unnecessary nesting of `X` and `y` pipelines.

The precise design is not fully clear to me, however. For instance, should there be two lists of steps? Or a single list, and we indicate in a second list whether the transformer is applied to `X` or `y`?
I've added existing instances of dunders in the top post, for context

> I've added existing instances of dunders in the top post, for context 

Thanks! Seeing the example related to the `*` operator overload for `TransformedTargetForecaster` makes it much clearer what you had in mind.

So - I share your concerns that having both `*` and `**` and having to think about the complexity of using `ForecastingPipeline` vs `TransformedTargetForecaster` might be confusing.  I know for myself at least I would end up having to remind myself which operator corresponded to which class every time I thought about using it, and thus either wouldn't use this shortcut, or it wouldn't end up saving me much time.  And I think that once you add in the fact that `ForecastingPipeline` can optionally take a `TransformedTargetForecaster` as a `Forecaster` you end up with a lot of complexity... and potentially the optionality to write hard to read/understand code chunks like `trans_X_1**trans_X_2**trans_y_1*trans_y_2*forecaster`.

But perhaps there is a way to reframe this problem so we abstract some of the complexity away from the user?  What are your thoughts on the following potential solution:

- since it seems like a lot of this complexity is springing up from the fact that we must keep track of whether a particular transformer should be applied to `X` or `y` my idea was to add a new property, lets call it `apply_transform_to` to the `Transformer` classes that kept track of whether that particular instance of the transformer object was intended for transforming `X` or `y` inputs? 
-  this `apply_transform_to` property could be configured to not change any of the pre-existing actions of the transformer, so as to hopefully not interfere with any pre-existing code or assumptions  🤞 . (and could have a sensible default, ie `either` or `X` or `y` depending on the `Transformer` in question.  This property could then optionally be set by the user at the time of creation of a new `Transformer` object or left at the deafult). 
- in addition we also create a new `Pipeline` class, lets call it `StackAllTransformsAndForecast` (feel free to suggest a better name haha) which has 2 `steps` properties: `steps_y` and `steps_X`. 
-  when a new `StackAllTransformsAndForecast` object is created the `__init__()` could then handle checking the `apply_transform_to` property for all transforms it was handed in the steps and adding them to either `step_X` or `step_y` (or complaining if the `apply_transform_to` property is not specified).  
- Note we could also easily extend this to accept pre-existing `TransformedTargetForecaster` or `ForecastingPipeline` objects as input as it would be easy to make sense of where the transformations associated with those object should go.
- lastly - we simply have the `*` operator handle create a `StackAllTransformsAndForecast` object, and simply require that transformers using the `*` operator have the `apply_transform_to` property set.
- now the user only has to keep in mind one special operator!
- and can create pipeline objects like so: `pipe = trans_1.apply_transform_to('X')*trans_2.apply_transform_to('X')*trans_3.apply_transform_to('y')*forecaster` which in my mind is more readable. 

Obviously some more details to hammer out on exactly how this might work, but curious on your thoughts/first impressions!

One issue with this is it could break pre-existing assumptions about the `*` operator creating a `TransformedTargetForecaster` object.  Personally I think it would be nice if the `*` was what we used for this as it just reads better - but perhaps you might have a sense of how long this feature has been around for/what it might break if we changed it. We could always default to your original suggestion of using `**` if needed. 

Another thing to consider is that if properly implemented `StackAllTransformsAndForecast` could in theory replace `TransformedTargetForecaster` and `ForecastingPipeline`.  Obviously we would keep the other two around, but could recommend that new users use the unified pipeline?

> So - I share your concerns that having both `*` and `**` and having to think about the complexity of using `ForecastingPipeline` vs `TransformedTargetForecaster` might be confusing.

Yes, exactly - that's why I have so far been holding off with the second operator.
Cognitive overload is a real danger here.

To give the things on the other side of the argument:
* Intuitively, you could think of `*` as "primary pipeline", i.e., it always acts on the "central data stream", and `**` acts on the "secondary data stream" if there is one. One star for primary, and two for secondary.
* comparisons should always be made to the alternative - and these are very complex nesting statements with name/estimator tuples. I think complexity is higher with the alternative.
* in [this discussion here](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/discussions/2451#discussioncomment-2561192)
@anthonygiorgio97 who apparently is in the habit of building complex pipelines, thought it might be useful

> since it seems like a lot of this complexity is springing up from the fact that we must keep track of whether a particular transformer should be applied to `X` or `y` my idea was to add a new property, lets call it `apply_transform_to` to the `Transformer` classes that kept track of whether that particular instance of the transformer object was intended for transforming `X` or `y` inputs?

Interesting idea! My first impulse was, this is maybe not a good idea. 
My second thought, looking at the final bullet point with the syntax: I think there's something interesting to it - perhaps attaching "apply_to" to the transformer is not exactly how to implement it, but perhaps there's sth similar.

Why I think this is maybe not a good idea: because this would violate the design principle of making specification of "how applied" extrinsic to the object. Phrased differently, what data a transformer is being applied to is not a "natural property" of the transformer, so shouldn't be attached to it.
I know that attaching the data or properties of it to the estimator is tempting - but that kind of design invites a number of problems around "mixing concerns" imo.

But, it is a new idea - so I'll take some time to think it through, and see whether we can have sth similar, syntax-wise.

Question: can you try to spell out why, in your mind, `.apply_transform_to('X')*` is more readable than `**`, why is `.apply_transform_to('y')*` more readable than `*`?

> in addition we also create a new Pipeline class, lets call it StackAllTransformsAndForecast (feel free to suggest a better name haha) which has 2 steps properties: steps_y and steps_X.

Yes, I think this is a good idea! I've considered it before.
The name perhaps not, though, although it wouldn't be much worse as all the other class names in sktime...

> Note we could also easily extend this to accept pre-existing TransformedTargetForecaster or ForecastingPipeline objects as input as it would be easy to make sense of where the transformations associated with those object should go.

Yes, that's also a good idea! I have not considered this!
This would allow us to use the "smaller" pipelines if only one input is acted upon, and make the change incremental until deprecation!

Re `steps_X` and `steps_y`, we seem to have to arrived at the same idea, independently, see here:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1174
That typically means that it's a good idea, or a tempting fallacy.

What do you think about `steps_y_to_X` in the issue?

>Question: can you try to spell out why, in your mind, .apply_transform_to('X')* is more readable than **, why is .apply_transform_to('y')* more readable than *?

Sure!  Here was my thinking: 

 - If I didn't write this code (or alternatively if I wrote it a while ago and forgot what I had been trying to do) I think the `.apply_transform_to('X')` version  vs the `**` and `*` version is closer to explaining itself (though I am not tied to having the syntax be in that exact form, just something like that!)!  

- Essentially - I think it would be easier to look at this pipeline and realize - ah there is a difference between `X` transformers and `y` transformers.  Maybe that impacts what the code is doing/maybe I will need to think about this for my own pipeline! With the `*` vs `**` alternatives you have to first notice that there is a difference between `**` and `*` and then go look it up to figure out what that difference is.

I see, yes, that makes sense.

Different question:
one problem that I have with your syntax is that you have the "apply_to" everywhere now.

What about sth like

`to_X(trafo1 * trafo2 * trafo3) * trafo4 * trafo5 * trafo6 * forecaster`?
Ah!  Yes that reads even better!

Or even:
`to_X(trafo1 * trafo2 * trafo3) * to_y(trafo4 * trafo5 * trafo6 )* forecaster` ?

> Essentially - I think it would be easier to look at this pipeline and realize - ah there is a difference between `X` transformers and `y` transformers.  Maybe that impacts what the code is doing/maybe I will need to think about this for my own pipeline! With the `*` vs `**` alternatives you have to first notice that there is a difference between `**` and `*` and then go look it up to figure out what that difference is.  

Can we analyze this further: what is the *differential* burden of having to look up `**` and `*`, vs not understanding the `*` and looking it up? What if we compare looking up `**` and `*` and `+`, vs having only `*` and `+`?
In your thought process, have you assumed that you "already know about `*`" or not?

>Can we analyze this further: what is the differential burden of having to look up ** and *, vs not understanding the * and looking it up? What if we compare looking up ** and * and +, vs having only * and +?
In your thought process, have you assumed that you "already know about *" or not?

Sure - to clarify - in my thought process the concern is that the theoretical me sees the first `*` and thinks, ah that makes sense, perhaps we are just joining these transformations together.... maybe the variable that we are assigning everything to is called `pipeline` so the theoretical me assumes that she understands what is going on and actually neglects to notice that there is also `**` in addition to `*`.   

Or to pick a different example - say I have only seen examples of `*` pipelines, but now I have a new application that also requires transformations applied to X!  I might not have any reason to look up `**`,  instead I might try to see if I can get `*` to work, realize I cannot and then get frustrated and do it another way.  Whereas the `to_X()` functionality might lead me to ask..... hmm maybe there is also a  `to_y()`?
in the first example, one hopes I might eventually notice the `*` vs `**` but in reality it might take me a bit of debugging/close reading! :)

> What do you think about steps_y_to_X in the issue?

as to your other question I think I would need to think about this more.  To understand what you are trying to do here - would we essentially be trying to create a "fake" `X` variable via some transformation of the `y` variable?  Hmm, to me this seems potentially troublesome as it seems to clash a bit non-intuitively with my understanding of what "exogenous" data should be.  ie - now we have something that we are treating as an `X`, but really is just some transformed feature extracted from `y`.  Does that make sense? 

However, I can definitely understand that there are time when extracting multiple features from `y` can be very useful for prediction tasks (especially if we perhaps had some way of learning what features were helpful)!   So - I am not necessarily saying what you are trying to achieve here is necessarily a bad idea, just that at first glance the syntax of `steps_y_to_X` doesn't totally sit right. 

[edit - I was also a bit confused by what you meant by 'overwrite' here as well]

Just throwing this out there as a sort of half baked idea- but what if we somehow had pipeline building block classes?  ie - an x_transform_block and a y_transform block?  Or alternatively a transform block that has an attribute which tracks whether it is an X block or a y block. 

Now calling `to_X()` or similar creates an x_transform block object can then be chained together with other blocks (ie a y transform block, a forecaster block) to form the pipeline class?  This could potentially also handle the advanced issue you mention in #1174 of being able to more easily allow for transformations after the forecasting step and it would take care of this issue:

>Why I think this is maybe not a good idea: because this would violate the design principle of making specification of "how applied" extrinsic to the object. Phrased differently, what data a transformer is being applied to is not a "natural property" of the transformer, so shouldn't be attached to it.
I know that attaching the data or properties of it to the estimator is tempting - but that kind of design invites a number of problems around "mixing concerns" imo.

Because now it is this block is keeping track of what it is being applied to instead of the transformers as I had originally suggested? (where for the blocks keeping track of what it is applied to might be a more "natural property"
The transformed `y` to `X` case is covered in this issue #1443 and requires also a shift to be used later as `X` in `predict`. A PR from me is linked but pending since longer 😐

@miraep8 you might also look here for a discussion on pipelining we had some time ago: https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/blob/main/steps/01_forecasting_api/forecasting_pipeline.md

Based on this, the `ForecastingPipeline` was implemented but we are still lacking a pipeline functionality that covers `y` and `X` trafo in one class.
Thanks @aiwalter !  It was useful to get a sense of what you all have already discussed/motivations.
